poem:
**The Last Hospital**

In Gaza's northern corner, silence falls  
where healing hands once labored.  
The echo of crumbling walls—  
a pause, appalling—questions the air.

In corridors now quiet,  
life's pulse is questioned, as whispers  
scatter among the ruins,  
wondering when the dawn shall care.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "WHO ‘appalled’ by Israel attack on northern Gaza’s last functioning major hospital The World Health Organization says it is “appalled” by an Israeli raid which it said had shut down and partly destroyed the last major hospital still functioning in northern Gaza. Israel’s “systematic dismantling of the health system” combined with a siege of the population in the north of the coastal strip over the past 80 days “puts the lives of the 75,000 Palestinians". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
